name: B-Complex Vitamins
summary: A group of eight essential B vitamins that support energy metabolism, neurological health, and stress resilience.
description: B-complex refers to the eight water-soluble B vitamins—B1 (thiamine), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (niacin), B5 (pantothenic acid), B6 (pyridoxine), B7 (biotin), B9 (folate), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins serve as cofactors in critical enzymatic reactions for energy production, neurotransmitter synthesis, red blood cell formation, and DNA repair. Supplementation may help address deficiencies caused by poor diet, alcoholism, medication use, or certain health conditions. B vitamins are also investigated for their roles in mood regulation, cognitive function, and stress resilience.

metadata.natural_source: Whole grains, legumes, leafy greens, eggs, dairy, meat, fortified foods
metadata.fda_status: Not FDA-approved; marketed as dietary supplement in U.S.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to any B vitamin formulation
monitoring_required: Vitamin B12, folate, and homocysteine levels in relevant patients

sections.text: B vitamins act as essential cofactors in enzymatic reactions. Thiamine (B1) supports carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function; Riboflavin (B2) participates in redox reactions; Niacin (B3) forms NAD/NADP for energy metabolism; Pantothenic acid (B5) is a precursor to coenzyme A; Pyridoxine (B6) aids in neurotransmitter and heme synthesis; Biotin (B7) is required for carboxylase activity; Folate (B9) and B12 are crucial for DNA synthesis and homocysteine metabolism.

adult.usual_range: Typical OTC complexes provide 50–100% of daily value for each B vitamin; therapeutic doses may be higher depending on deficiency state
adult.deficiency: Varies by vitamin (e.g., B12 injections 1000 mcg/month, folate 400–1000 mcg/day)

sections.pediatric: Varies by age and dietary requirements
sections.geriatric: May require higher B12 due to absorption decline

sections.text: Correction of deficiency symptoms may be seen in days to weeks. Neurological recovery from B12 deficiency may take months.

serious: Neuropathy with very high B6 doses

other: High-dose B6 (>200 mg/day) can cause sensory neuropathy.
Niacin at therapeutic doses may cause hepatotoxicity and flushing.
Excessive folate can mask B12 deficiency, risking neurological injury.

items: Vitamin B12 and folate levels in at-risk patients
Homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (if deficiency suspected)

sections.pregnancy: Folate supplementation strongly recommended; B-complex is safe at dietary doses
sections.lactation: Generally safe; supports maternal and infant needs
sections.geriatrics: B12 deficiency more common; consider higher supplementation

sections.text: No taper required; safe to discontinue when no longer needed.

items: B12 and folate are particularly critical in psychiatry and neurology due to their impact on mood and cognition.
Stress formulations often include higher doses of B5 (pantothenic acid) and B6 (pyridoxine).
High-dose injections are sometimes used in complementary medicine, though evidence is mixed.
